string.Text: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.Text:
Welcome to this presentation on vocabulary techniques.

To navigate through this presentation, click the tiles on the bottom of the screen to jump to a specific technique.

Click the R tile at the top right of the screen to view additional resources.

You can jump back to the title screen by clicking the house tile, learn more about the pedagogy and best practices of vocabulary instruction by clicking the book tile, or test your knowledge by clicking the test tile.

Click a tile on the bottom of the screen to see the techniques.

1. Write down or print vocabulary words on index cards or post it notes.

2. Split students into groups of 3-5 and have each group sit at their own table.

3. Place the index cards or post-it notes face down on the table.

4. Each student picks up a card and holds the card on their forehead so that the other students can see.

5. Students should NOT look at their own cards!

6. Students then take turns asking questions about their vocabulary word until they can guess what it is.

7. Then they pick a new card and repeat.

1. Put a chair in front of the white board facing away from the board (so that the student’s back will be to the board).

2. Split students into teams and designate one team to go first.

3. Ask one student to come up and sit in the ‘hot seat’.

4. Write a word on the board so that the team can see but the student in the hot seat can’t.

5. The team must give clues to the student in the hot seat for them to guess the word on the board but cannot say the word or any part of the word.

6. After 15 seconds if the student cannot guess the word, the turn is over and no points are awarded.

7. If the student guesses correctly, the team earns 10 points and it becomes the next team’s turn.

8. Rotate through students so that all members of each team must be in the hot seat - don’t allow the same student to go multiple times unless all others have already gone.

9. Play to a certain amount of points or until the list of vocabulary is exhausted.

`1. Split students into teams.

2. One student from the first team comes to the board and draws a picture of a vocabulary word or describes a concept with pictures.

3. His or her team members have 20 seconds to guess what it is from the time they start drawing.

4. If they get it right, award 10 points.

5. If they cannot guess within the 20 seconds, the other team has a chance to steal the points if they can guess the word.

6. Then repeat with the other team.

1. Choose 10 categories from the unit and list them on the board.

2. Have students copy them down (or number their paper 1-10) and then choose a letter from the alphabet.

3. Give students 1 minute to write words that fall under each category beginning with that letter of the alphabet.

4. When the time is up, tell students to put their pens down and ask for the answers students came up with.

5. For each unique answer, the student who came up with it gets 1 point.

6. If more than one student has the same answer, no students get a point for that word.

7. The goal is to find unique ways to fill the categories. (<http://letterdice.iphonemarks.com/> you can use this letter dice to choose the letter).

1. Write 15-25 vocabulary words on the board or project them from a PowerPoint.

2. Split students into two teams.

3. Have students line up facing the board in two lines.

4. Have the first student from each team come to the board.

5. Give each student a fly swatter.

6. Read the definition of a vocabulary word and the first student to swat it on the board (correctly) gets the point for their team.

7. The two students go to the end of their respective lines and the next two students come up and repeat.

1. Split students into teams.

2. Designate one team to go first.

3. Ask the team (or a specific student) a question or read the definition of a word.

4. If they get the question or word right, give them 5 points.

5. Keep track of points on the board.

6. Then (if they got it right) they can throw a paper ball into the trashcan.

7. If they make the shot, double the points.

8. Repeat this with the other team

1. Cut up 2 sets of vocabulary words and definitions so that each word is on its own piece of paper and each definition is on its own.

2. Split each set in two so that one pile contains the vocabulary words and a separate pile contains the definitions.

3. Tape the vocabulary words and definitions on the wall but mix them up so that any given word is not next to its definition.

4. Do this for both sets of words and definitions but put one set on one side of the room and the other on the other side so that students won’t get distracted from the other team.

5. Split students into teams of two and have them work together to match all the definitions and words.

6. The first team to finish wins.

7. You could also do this with examples, synonyms, or antonyms, instead of definitions.

1. Split the class into two teams.

2. Designate one team to bat and the other to pitch.

3. One student from the pitching team will say a vocabulary word.

4. Then one student from the batting team will give the definition or use the vocabulary word in a sentence.

5. If the definition or example is correct, they move to first base (designate one side of the room).

6. Then the next student from the batting team comes up and a new pitcher gives them another word.

7. If they give the correct definition or use it in a sentence correctly, they will move to first base and the player on first will go to second (the back of the room) and so on (students can only move one base at a time).

8. If a batting student gets the definition/sentence/example wrong, the batting team gets one strike.

9. After 3 strikes the batting and pitching team switch and the previous batting team becomes the pitching team and vice versa.

10. The batting team can continue until the set of words is exhausted or they get 3 strikes.

11. You may want to set a time limit (per inning) of 3 minutes per team if your students are getting all the answers correct.

12. This game works best when you have a lot of vocabulary words to practice.

1. Create two sets of index cards, one with the vocabulary words on them and the other with the definitions.

2. Give each student a word and a definition (make sure that each student has a different word and definition).

3. Then ask students to get up and walk around to other students and read their definitions until they find the student with the word on their index card.

4. When they find their match, the person with the word gives the index card to the person with the definition so that in the end, all students will be left with 1 matching word and definition.

1. Put students into groups of 3-5.

2. Tell students to choose 5-10 vocabulary words from the unit and write definitions or sentences in their own words on white boards, leaving a blank for the word if used in a sentence.

3. They should NOT include the answer.

4. When all groups have written their sentences, the groups rotate to a different group’s board and try to solve the sentences.

5. They should write on their own paper/clipboard/tablet and NOT on the white board.

6. After they have all solved the other groups sentences (or time is up) they rotate again to another group’s board and repeat.

7. To speed things up, give groups 2 minutes to solve the sentences on each board.

Welcome to this course on Vocabulary Instruction and Techniques.

There are 3 modules in this course.

In the first module, you will learn about the pedagogy and best practices of vocabulary instruction.

In the 2nd module, you will see many different techniques you can use to introduce, practice and review vocabulary with your students.

And finally in the 3rd module, you will test your knowledge by suggesting strategies and techniques for three different scenarios and explain your reasoning with support from the first module.

If you’d like to see more resources on vocabulary instruction and techniques, click the R tile at any time to jump to the resources slide.

Click the Instruction tile to begin.

Is this your first time taking this presentation?

If so, click the Y tile to watch a brief tutorial on how to navigate through this presentation.

If you’ve participated in a presentation like this before, click the N tile to continue.
Welcome to the Vocabulary Instruction course module.
Before we start talking about the pedagogy of vocabulary instruction, let’s do a quick thinking exercise to help you contextualize what you are going to learn.
I would argue that there are really just 2 main parts of your course content: 2 to 3 big picture concepts and then about 100 or 200 vocabulary words that help explain those concepts.
What are the major topics, themes or ideas that you want students to understand deeply by the end of your course?
Pause this video here and write them down now.

Do you have them written down?

Good.

Do you have them written down?

Good.
Now that you have identified those big picture concepts, think about the course vocabulary that is essential to understanding and expanding those concepts.
The goal of your vocabulary instruction then is to present students with as many opportunities as possible to make connections between the course vocabulary and those big picture concepts.

In this module, we’ll be studying the pedagogy and best practices of vocabulary instruction and the use of different techniques to introduce, practice and review vocabulary so that you can give your students the maximum number of opportunities to connect the vocabulary to the course concepts and learn and study, more effectively.
By the time you finish this course, you’ll be able to identify, evaluate and select methods to facilitate research-based techniques to teach vocabulary.
Click NEXT to begin.

Let’s begin with a reflection.

How did you learn the vocabulary for your course?

Take a second and think about some of the strategies you used.


When you’re ready, click NEXT to continue.

You may have learned the words by reading them in the context of a textbook, journal article or website.

You may have had them presented to you by a teacher and written them down in your notes.

Maybe you wrote and rewrote the words until you felt you had a full grasp of the meaning.

Or maybe you created flashcards to test yourself.

There are many ways to learn and practice new vocabulary words, but which way is the most effective?

This module will walk you through research-based strategies and techniques to make your vocabulary instruction more effective!


Click NEXT to continue.

Let’s start with a pre-test!

Define the terms in your own words.

If you aren’t sure of the meaning or you don’t know the full definition of the word, take a guess or write any details that come to mind when you read the word.

When you’re finished click SUBMIT on the form.

Then click NEXT to continue.

How do you introduce new vocabulary?

Take a second to reflect on how you normally introduce your new vocabulary words to your students.

When you’re ready, click NEXT to continue.

As we discussed at the beginning of this module, there are many ways to introduce new vocabulary.

You could do a pre-test (as we just did),

you could introduce new vocabulary in the context of a reading assignment or in the lecture where you can explain the meaning and correct misunderstandings immediately,

you could play vocabulary games to introduce the new words

or you could give students a list of vocabulary words and their definitions.

While all of these methods may have a place and time, there’s one method I’d like to discourage you from using to introduce new words to your students.

Click NEXT to continue.
Which of the following methods shouldn’t you use to introduce new vocabulary?

Take a look at this quote from Robert Marzano:

When students copy the teacher's explanation or description of a term instead of generating their own explanation, the results are not as strong. Ideally, student explanations should come from their own lives.

When students write down and define the terms in their own words, they are actively building their knowledge rather than passively accepting it.

A vocabulary list with definitions may be useful as a study guide in that it tells students WHAT to study, but it doesn’t actually help them with our first big take-away…

Click NEXT to find out what our first important take-away is.

Retrieval!

Were you able to come up with a definition for retrieval on the pre-test?

Retrieval is act of trying to recall something from memory without looking at your notes or re-reading.

Things like flashcard drilling, re-writing what you remember from notes you took without looking, and taking closed-book quizzes are all examples of retrieval practice.

This brings us to our big picture concept for this course.

What’s the difference between Assessment FOR learning and Assessment OF learning?

At first it may seem like just semantics, but the difference is very important.

With retrieval practice, we are testing our students and encouraging our students to test themselves so that they will learn the material BETTER.

This is assessment FOR learning – learning through tests, quizzes and other low-stakes assignments that force students to retrieve information.

Assessment OF learning is like the final test.

This is used to see what students know at a particular time and usually it is connected to a grade.

While Assessment OF learning is definitely beneficial to metacognition and identifying gaps in knowledge, unless paired with quality feedback, assessment OF learning, usually does not lead to better learning.

Click NEXT to find out more.

Let’s practice retrieval now!

How many words from the pre-test can you remember?

Use the text fields below to type in as many of the vocabulary words as you can remember.

You will have 30 seconds.

Ready?

3-2-1

GO!

Times up!

How many could you remember?

Why did you remember the words you did?

Maybe you remembered the last word on the list, maybe you made some connection to something else that had a similar meaning or sounded the same, or maybe you already knew something about those words.

Whatever the case, retrieval of this information helps to solidify these words in your working memory.

If you’d like to see a follow up activity that you can use in the classroom, click the “Classroom Activity” link here.

Or click NEXT to continue.

Before you see a list of the words again, if you were doing this activity with your students, this would be a good time to ask them to share notes with a partner.

After trying to recall as many words as they can, allow students to compare their list with a neighbor’s and add any words their partner remembered that they missed.

This gives students another opportunity to make connections with the words and further commit them to memory.

Click NEXT to see the full list of words.

Another great way to increase students’ metacognition is to have them rate themselves on how familiar they are with the words.

By asking students to rate their knowledge on a Likert scale from 0-3, students can identify the gaps in their own knowledge and can work to fill them.

Let’s practice this now.

On the Form, rate your familiarity with each of the vocabulary words, 0 being that you’ve never seen the word before and 3 being that you can define the term in your own words.

When you’re finished, click SUBMIT on the form.

Then click NEXT to continue.

Now that you’ve assessed your understanding, let’s find out what these words really mean.

Click on a word in the list to see the definition of each word.

Read the definition and on the Google Form, type in an example of the word.

Make sure you click SUBMIT on the Google Form to contribute your answer.

Then click the BACK arrow on each slide to return to the definitions slide.

Then repeat the process with the next word on the list.

You will be asked to test your knowledge of these words again shortly, so take your time reading through the definitions and coming up with examples.

When you’ve finished reading the definitions and giving examples of all the words, click NEXT to continue.

Now let’s talk about dual coding.

If you have been reading the transcript and listening to the audio, you have already experienced dual coding!

If you read the definition, you know that dual coding is the practice of combining two forms of media to describe a word.

This could be text and a picture, text and audio, audio and a picture or text and video, just to name a few.

We’re going to be looking at two ways to encourage students to use dual coding to practice vocabulary.

Click NEXT to find out how.

Google Sites and Slides allow students to work together to dual code using images and text to define words and give examples.

If you’d like to learn more about creating an illustrated dictionary using Google Sites or creating digital flashcards using Google Slides, click on the boxes below to watch a brief tutorial video about each.

After you watch the video, you will have the opportunity to collaborate with others taking this course to work on an illustrated dictionary and a set of digital flashcards.

If you would like to skip these activities, click next to continue, but remember that you can return to this slide at any time by clicking the table of contents tab and clicking on Dual Coding with Google.

Google Sites allows students to collaborate in order to create a website in real time.

We are going to use the new Google Sites to create an illustrated dictionary using the vocabulary terms from our lesson.

When you do this with your students, you can assign specific students to create sub-pages for different words, or group them and have each group create an illustrated dictionary of their own.

Click on the video to watch a brief step-by-step tutorial.

Then click the Try It! tile to try for yourself.

This will open a new tab and you may be asked to sign into Google to participate.

When you’re finished, come back to this tab and click NEXT to continue to the next section or click the Flashcards tile to learn about creating digital flashcards with Google Slides.

Google Slides also allows students to collaborate in real-time, however instead of a website, using Google Slides, students can work together to create a presentation.

In this case, instead of a presentation, we are going to use Google Slides to create digital flashcards so that we can use them as a study tool.

Click the Video to watch a step-by-step demonstration of how to create flashcards using Google Slides.

Then click the Try It tile to go to the Google Slides presentation and try it for yourself by creating a slide for a word from your course.

When you’re finished, click NEXT to continue, or click the Dictionary tile to learn how to create an illustrated dictionary using Google Sites

For our last activity, let’s talk about Elaboration.

Elaboration is expanding on a word or concept in order to make as many connections as possible to your prior knowledge.

Simply put, elaboration is talking about a word until you exhaust your knowledge of the subject.

Now let’s look at a fun way to get students to practice Elaboration.

Click NEXT to continue.

Concept cubes are 6-sided dice that students can take turns rolling in order to practice elaboration on a word or concept.

Click the VIDEO INSTRUCTIONS link to watch a short video on how to play,

Then test your elaboration skills using the digital concept cubes here.

When you’re finished, click NEXT to continue to the post-test.

Now let’s test your knowledge.

How well do you understand these important vocabulary concepts?

Take the quiz and click SUBMIT on the form to check your understanding.

When you’re finished, click NEXT to learn more techniques you can use in your vocabulary instruction.

You completed the first module of the Vocabulary Instruction and Techniques course.

Click NEXT to return to the home screen.

Then continue on to Module Two: “Vocabulary Techniques” to learn more techniques you can use to teach vocabulary.

OR

Click “Test Your Knowledge” to check your understanding of the principles and techniques with a Scenarios quiz.

Congratulations! You made it to the final assessment!

On the form, you will be presented with 3 different scenarios of instructors that want to introduce, practice or review vocabulary.

Choose the most appropriate technique for each of the 3 scenarios and explain your reasoning.

Be as detailed as possible and BE SURE to include the vocabulary principles and concepts discussed in this module to support why the techniques and methods of facilitation you choose will be effective.

When you’re finished, click SUBMIT and contact Mike to receive your final score.

After you complete the assessment, click NEXT to return to the home screen.
